name: Hello world
description: Hello world.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
As you can see the function we're defining takes a callback 
function that must be invoked when the code is completed.
Since this code will run in a Node.js environment the callback
will take as a first argument an error and as a second argument 
the result which can be a string, a number, or an object that will 
be stringified as JSON.

name: Accessing console
description: How to see real time console.logs.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
For debugging purposes can be useful have a look at the variable
values by using console.log. You can see real time logs by enabling
the console from the Editor.

After each Code Block execution you can see the request and the
response body in the Stamplay Editor from the Logs view.

name: Handling errors
description: How to handle errors in Code Blocks.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
Sometimes you just want to return an error, other time you just want to handle it in a nicer way.
The callback function can be invoked with a string or an object that has the property `message` in it in order to make the CodeBlock return with an error.

name: Random number
description: How to generate a random number using a Code Block.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
In this example the CodeBlock will return a random number between 1 and 100.
We'll extend later this feature by making the minimum and maximum value parametric by query parameter or via query params.

name: Asynchronous code
description: Asynchronous code execution in Code Blocks.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
Since you have a callback you can execute any kind of asynchronous code you like.
Here you can see that we're just using the setTimeout function but you can connect to a database (but make sure to use secrets!), execute a query and then return the results of the query.
Please note that a CodeBlock execution can last at maximum 60 seconds.

name: Making HTTP requests
description: How to make HTTP request in Code Blocks .

note.title: instructions
note.content:
Since you're executing Node.js code you are able to do HTTP[S] requests from your CodeBlock in a really easy way.
To make your life easier you can use the request module and many others.

name: Hello name
description: How to access to request body or query parameter.

note.title: instructions
note.content: In order to access request body and/or the request query parameter you have to use a different function signature that takes a context and a callback.

name: Accessing request
description: How to access to request body or query parameter.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
In order to access request body and/or the request query parameter you have to use a different function signature that takes a context and a callback.
This example is showing you a CodeBlock that is getting the url parameter in query string is trying to resolve its IP address. 
If an error occurs the callback will be invoked with the error and it will be back to the client, otherwise a 200 response will be sent.
If you want to distinct query parameters from the body parameters you can access the request parameters as follows
query parameters in context.query
body parameters in context.body
secrets in context.secrets
context.data is just a convenient way to merge all the request parameters in an accessible key.

name: Handling secrets
description: How to access secrets in Code Blocks.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
Since the server side of an application is the one that keeps passwords, tokens and connections string the CodeBlocks allows you to store this kind of informations securely by using the secret area in the Editor.
All the secrets stored in that area are saved encrypted and you can use it in your Codeblock by accessing to context.secrets.yourKey. Please avoid to return these values to the client.
In this example we're making an HTTP request with the authorization header using a password stored securely in the key named secretKey.

name: Parametric random number
description: How to access to request body or query parameter.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
In this example the CodeBlock will return a random number between 1 and 100.
We'll extend later this feature by making the minimum and maximum value parametric by query parameter or via query params.

name: Levenshtein distance
description: How to compute Levenshtein distance across two strings using the fast-levenshtein distance.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
This example will allow you to create an API endpoint for your application that will be able to compute the Levenshtein distance between two given strings.
We're using the module fast-levenshtein which is available in the CodeBlocks, the input is allowed from both request body and query parameters.

name: Connecting to a database
description: How to connect to an external Redis database using a Code Block.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
One of the coolest thing you can do with a server is connecting at your own database, and you can do it with CodeBlocks too!
You can look for the available Node.js modules that you can use here
Mongo
Redis
MySql
Apache Cassandra
are only an example of what we can connect to.
In this example we will connect to an external Redis database the url, the port and the password are encrypted in order to not leak any kind of private information.

After the connection and the authentication we're saving a value, retrieving it and returning to the client, few lines of code that saved us from creating a Node.js server and managing during all its lifetime.

name: Face detection with Cloudinary
description: Face detection made easy using Cloudinary service and node module.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
Our available modules include among third party services Cloudinary, an image and video managment on the cloud.
Here is an example of how to use it for uploading an image on their service and request a face detection.
After requiring and configuring the library using the secrets area in order to save the key and the secret, 
we're uploading the image from an url and requesting the face detection feature.

name: Twitter APIs
description: Retrieve all the follower of a specified Twitter username.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
In this example we're using the twit module in order to use the Twitter APIs.
 After configuring the library saving all the Twitter authentication tokens the as secrets, we're first asking all the ids of the Stamplay's Twitter account and then we're using async module in order to process them and retrieve information for each one of them.
 Please note that due to Twitter's API limit requests, this script may not work properly with accounts that has an high number of followers.

name: Response with custom headers
description: How to send custom response headers.

note.title: instructions
note.content: We can easily add some custom headers to the response since that with full control we can control everything.

name: Accessing the request
description: How to access the raw request.

note.title: instructions
note.content:
In order to have a full control of the CodeBlock we need to use a third, different function signature that takes three arguments context,req and res.
In this example we'll send a json in the response but since now we've got control full control of it we'll need to set the correct Content-Type manually.
This kind of control open to developers infinite use cases that process the request in different and unusual ways.

name: Handling multipart/form-data content-type
description: How to handle multipart/form-data content-type

note.title: instructions
note.content:
With full control function signature since we have the raw request we can afford to parse the multipart/form-data content type.
To do so we need to disable the Parse body property that can be found in the Properties tab.
In this example we'll send a file and using the node module named multiparty we'll parse the request in order to access the fields and the files server side.

name: Automatically tag new versions
description: A Code Block that can be used as a Github webhook to automatically tag new versions based on changes to the file package.json.

note.title: Instructions
note.content:
• - Create a Github API token with repo access from: https://github.com/settings/tokens/new.
  • - Go to https://github.com/:user/:repository/settings/hooks/new.
  • - Use the url of this Code Block as Payload URL.
  • - Click on Add Webhook.

Note: Requires a secret called GITHUB_TOKEN containing your GitHub access token.
